title: Packages built in debug mode should not purge sources
body:
As a user I want packages that are built in debug mode to NOT delete their source files after a successful build so that I can map assembly lines to the corresponding lines of the sources when debugging.

### Rationale

During the build of packages Spack currently uses a *staging area* (where sources are expanded and built) and  a *prefix* (where binaries or other artifacts are installed). The staging area is usually deleted upon a successful build, to avoid wasting disk space. As the  staging area contains the source files this operation renders any installed binary with debug symbols mostly unusable for debug purposes.

### Description

A simple solution to this issue could be to move the *staging area* to e.g. `<prefix>/.spack/sources` when packages are built with debug symbols (and avoid removing that directory, of course). This solution could be optimized for space by further separating  the *staging area* into a:
- a *source area* where source files are expanded
- a *build area* where the compilation process is executed

and move only the *source area* into a sub-folder of `<prefix>`. This latter solution requires packages to be buildable out of source.

### Additional information
I think this feature might become even more useful when #9612 will be merged, as people will be facilitated in setting-up development environments that will probably build stuff in debug mode.
